Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Linking Beliefs about the Social Consequences of Emotions with Emotional Behavior
Award.AbstractNarration:
Emotion regulation and emotional behavior depend on cultural context, but the mechanisms underlying these cultural differences are unclear. Recent work has found that the belief that emotions spread predicts reports of increased emotional expression and support seeking in Americans. The proposed study extends previous research to 1) identify the relationships between the beliefs that emotions spread and in-the-moment emotional behavior, and 2) explore whether these relationships are consistent across cultural contexts or are culturally dependent. Assessing the relationship between emotion beliefs and behaviors in two cultural contexts with documented differences in models of emotion will contribute to a more nuanced understanding of emotional behavior across cultural contexts. This understanding may improve the ability for international and multicultural settings, such as workplaces and schools, to facilitate intercultural interactions and benefit from their diversity. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Eunkook Suh at Yonsei University in Korea.

In order to test these questions, American and Korean participants will be primed to think that emotions are either very easily spread or not easily spread. Emotional behavior will be assessed through videos of participants describing recent emotional experiences as if they were speaking to a close friend. It is hypothesized that European Americans primed with the belief that emotions spread will express higher levels of positive and negative emotions. If this pattern reflects basic emotional processes, it is expected that Korean participants will also be more expressive following this prime. However, concern about the negative consequences of emotions on relationships and interactions is more salient in Korean than American contexts. If the relationship between the belief that emotions spread and emotional behavior depends on culture, Koreans may be less likely to express emotions following the prime that they spread easily to others. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In previous work, I found evidence that the more American participants believed their emotions spread, the more they reported expressing their emotions and seeking support following their positive and negative emotional experiences. The present research aimed to 1) identify the relationships between the belief that emotions spread, in-the-moment emotional behavior, and expectations of support from others and 2) explore whether these relationships are consistent across cultural contexts or are culturally dependent.

In order to test these questions, European American and Korean participants were randomly assigned to read one of three fabricated newspaper articles designed to prime distinct ideas about the effects of their emotions on others. One group of participants read an article about how emotions spread very easily from person to person, another group read an article about how each individual’s emotions are quite separate from others’, and a third control group read an unrelated article. We then recorded all participants as they discussed a positive and a negative emotional experience as if they were speaking to a close friend. These videos contain data on each participant’s use of emotion words to discuss their experiences as well as their nonverbal emotional behavior (i.e., facial behavior, posture). Following each discussion, participants were also asked about the level of support they would expect to receive from the friend they had imagined talking to.

I predicted that, replicating survey research, American participants would express their emotions more and would expect more support when they were led to believe that emotions spread. Past research has demonstrated that Koreans seek support less often than do Americans because they are more concerned about the potential negative consequences for their relationships (Taylor, Sherman, Kim, Jarcho, Tagaki, & Dunagan, 2004). If the relationship between the belief that emotions spread and emotional behavior depends on culture, I hypothesized that Koreans would be less likely to openly express their emotions when they were led to believe that emotions spread easily to others. However, if the patterns identified in my survey research reflect basic emotion processes, I hypothesized that Korean participants would, like Americans, express their emotions more and would expect more support from their friend when led to believe that emotions spread.

The videos containing data on participants’ actual emotional behavior are currently being processed, so I am unable to report on this aspect of the results at this time. However, the survey results of participants’ expectations of support from their friends have been processed and analyzed. When discussing negative emotional experiences, both Korean and American participants expected more support from their friends when led to believe that emotions spread than in either of the other two groups. When discussing positive experiences, the experimental manipulations have no effect on either Koreans’ or Americans’ expectations of support. These data have been presented at the following conferences: Society for Personality and Social Psychology, Society for Affective Science, and Association for Psychological Science. However, they have not yet been published in a peer-reviewed journal, and as such should be considered preliminary findings.

This research project contributes to a growing body of research aimed at developing a more nuanced understanding of the factors driving emotional behavior across cultural contexts. This research also demonstrates that beliefs about the spread of emotions can be manipulated and positively impact perceptions of social support.
